author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Many of us these days are oscillating between projects and ease: Make chile-oil fried eggs or yaki onigiri, miso chicken with radishes or pierogies.
content: Good morning. What are we, a year into this now? Stuck at home, out of work, too much work, low on funds, plenty money but worried all the same? It’s getting to the point where the beautiful days are the hardest, when it’d be great to be out in the world, cruising the boardwalk on a rusty bike, hiking a tree line near the Labrador border, laughing at the sunshine in a crowded Trafalgar Square.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seven States to Coordinate on Amassing Medical Equipment to Fight Coronavirus
description: New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island will unite to purchase medical supplies.
content: A group of Eastern states announced Sunday that they would band together to purchase and allocate the massive amounts of personal protective equipment and medical equipment needed to fight the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 4, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: Democrats, It’s Time to Consider a Plan B
description: Tara Reade’s allegations against Joe Biden demand action.
content: If you’re lucky when you report your sexual assault, you’ll become known as a person who was sexually assaulted. If you’re unlucky, you’ll become known as a person who lied about being sexually assaulted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: The Pandemic Isn’t Changing Everything
description: It is just speeding up trends that were already underway.
content: A crisis as life-altering as the coronavirus pandemic naturally inspires speculation about how it will change everything. But it is worth recalling that a far deadlier predecessor, the Spanish Flu, killed 50 million to 100 million people between 1918 and 1920, and was followed by the Roaring ’20s. So did it change anything?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Eggers
title: Flattening the Truth on Coronavirus
description: All your questions about the pandemic, answered. Sort of.
content: The People (P): What is happening?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: A Thousand Goodbyes for McCarter Theater’s Emily Mann
description: A virtual send-off for the artistic director and playwright drew more attendees than could have fit under a tent. “I liked this better,” she said.
content: Had this been a normal spring, Emily Mann would have wrapped up her three decades as artistic director of McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., in the traditional way, with colleagues and patrons gathered under a tent to toast her at a gala. Instead, on Saturday night, they gave her a virtual tribute on Zoom, which she watched, teary-eyed, from her living room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Ronan O’Rahilly, Pioneer of Pirate Radio, Is Dead at 79
description: He said he was in the “why-not” business. And his Radio Caroline became the soundtrack of British and European youth in the 1960s.
content: It was on the Saturday before Easter 1964 that Radio Caroline sent out its opening salvo, the Rolling Stones’ cover of Buddy Holly’s “Not Fade Away,” from a rehabilitated Dutch ferry anchored three miles off the coast of England. For British teenagers, used to a bland diet of children’s programs, 1950s ballads and farm news on the BBC — also known by the nickname Auntie — it was a revelation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: I’m Staying Put in New York. It’s Still Glorious.
description: Readers predict a recovery that may be different from the city we knew. Also: Simple recipes, please; an economy that will rebound.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tracing and Sampling to Monitor Covid-19
description: Readers suggest that: businesses that reopen keep customer logs, everyone keep a daily diary and random sampling be done widely.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman, Sapna Maheshwari and Michael J. de la Merced
title: J. Crew Likely to File for Bankruptcy in Virus’s First Big Retail Casualty
description: It was struggling before the coronavirus pandemic, but J. Crew is unlikely to be the last retailer to fall.
content: J. Crew, the mass-market clothing company whose preppy-with-a-twist products were worn by Michelle Obama and appeared at New York Fashion Week, is expected to file for bankruptcy protection as soon as Monday. It would be the first major retailer to fall during the coronavirus pandemic, though other big industry names including Neiman Marcus and J.C. Penney are likewise struggling with the devastating toll of mass shutdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Venezuelan Officials Claim to Have Stopped an Armed Incursion
description: The government said eight men had been killed and two captured in a foiled coup attempt, which officials attributed to Colombia and the United States.
content: CARACAS — The Venezuelan government said security forces foiled an armed incursion Sunday morning near the capital, Caracas, killing eight men and capturing the remaining two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Global Backlash Builds Against China Over Coronavirus
description: As calls for inquiries and reparations spread, Beijing has responded aggressively, mixing threats with aid and adding to a growing mistrust of China.
content: BRUSSELS — Australia has called for an inquiry into the origin of the virus. Germany and Britain are hesitating anew about inviting in the Chinese tech giant Huawei. President Trump has blamed China for the contagion and is seeking to punish it. Some governments want to sue Beijing for damages and reparations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Masks Become a Flash Point in the Virus Culture Wars
description: As people resume going out in public in the middle of a pandemic, to wear or not to wear a face mask has become a personal statement and sometimes a political one.
content: ATLANTA — As the nation edges away from lockdown and people once again share public spaces in the middle of a pandemic, wearing a face mask — or refusing to — has become a flash point in a moment when civic rules are being rewritten, seemingly on the fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Therapists and Patients Find Common Ground: Virus-Fueled Anxiety
description: Therapists in New York must deal with a parade of coronavirus-fueled anxieties, from their patients and from themselves.
content: On a good day, New York City is awash in its neuroses, a tightly wound place where a wide assortment of sky-scraping anxieties can build to an almost comic crescendo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Anti-Vaccination Activists Are Growing Force at Virus Protests
description: Public health experts fear that their messaging could further harm the country’s response to the pandemic.
content: The protest on Friday in Sacramento urging California’s governor to reopen the state resembled the rallies that have appeared elsewhere in the country, with crowds flocking to the State Capitol, pressing leaders to undo restrictions on businesses and daily life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Says U.S. Death Toll Could Reach 100,000
description: Defending his response to the pandemic, the president told a Fox News town hall that initial intelligence briefings suggested the outbreak was “not a big deal.”
content: This briefing has ended. Follow the latest updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson and Michael D. Shear
title: Before Covid-19, Trump Aide Sought to Use Disease to Close Borders
description: The president’s chief adviser on immigration, Stephen Miller, had long tried to halt migration based on public health, without success. Then came the coronavirus.
content: From the early days of the Trump administration, Stephen Miller, the president’s chief adviser on immigration, has repeatedly tried to use an obscure law designed to protect the nation from diseases overseas as a way to tighten the borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Billions’ and ‘Westworld’
description: Paul Giamatti and Damian Lewis return for the fifth run of Showtime’s drama, while the third season of HBO’s sci-fi series wraps up.
content: BILLIONS 9 p.m. on Showtime. “Billions,” a critics’ darling about power politics and high finance in New York, returns just in time to fill the “Homeland”-shaped void in Showtime’s schedule. Last season’s détente between the federal government watchdog Chuck (Paul Giamatti) and the hedge-fund king Axe (Damian Lewis) did not last long. In Season 5, the pair are yet again determined to take each other down, while new foes complicate matters. Julianna Margulies (“The Good Wife”) and Corey Stoll (“House of Cards”) join the show as recurring cast members. She plays a professor and author on sex and relationships; he takes the role of a social impact pioneer that challenges Axe’s power. And as Chuck butts heads with a dogged district attorney (Roma Maffia), his increasingly independent wife, Wendy (Maggie Siff), forges unexpected alliances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: George W. Bush Calls for End to Pandemic Partisanship
description: In a video, the former president, who generally avoids speaking out on current affairs, urged Americans to “remember how small our differences are” in a time of crisis. President Trump swiped at him in response.
content: WASHINGTON — Former President George W. Bush called on Americans on Saturday to put aside partisan differences, heed the guidance of medical professionals and show empathy for those stricken by the coronavirus and the resulting economic devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Who’s Ready to Go Shopping?
description: The country’s economy is starting to reopen. But health officials warn against moving too fast.
content: Limping businesses are preparing to reopen across the country, and some Americans are raring to get out of the house. Is this the beginning of the economy’s recovery or will it lead to a resurgence of coronavirus infections? Here’s the business news you need to know for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: As Putin Dallies, Russia’s Small Businesses Are Withering Away
description: The Russian president, who seems to share the traditional Soviet view of entrepreneurs as “swindlers,” is doing little to help them through a coronavirus lockdown.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Two weeks into the coronavirus lockdown, Aleksandr B. Zatulivetrov, a Russian businessman, had had enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Foresees Virus Death Toll as High as 100,000 in the United States
description: But even as President Trump acknowledged that the coronavirus has been deadlier than he had previously predicted, he pressed to reopen the country.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump predicted on Sunday night that the death toll from the coronavirus pandemic ravaging the country may reach as high as 100,000 in the United States, far worse than he had forecast just weeks ago, even as he pressed states to reopen the shuttered economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Beirut’s Nightlife Survived Civil War. Can It Withstand Pandemic?
description: In Lebanon’s capital, it’s a point of pride that the party never stopped, even during war and protests. But will the dancing and drinking come back after the coronavirus lockdown?
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When the disruptive threat of the coronavirus first came for Beirut, I was, appropriately enough, in a local bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Sass
title: I Bought a Car From Northern Italy as the Pandemic Took Hold
description: The little blue coupe’s journey shows how ordinary things played out in extraordinary circumstances.
content: Imagine what it would have been like to unwittingly arrange to buy an oxcart in Pompeii on or about the 23rd of August, 79 A.D. — I’m the 21st-century version of that guy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Pompeo Ties Coronavirus to China Lab, Despite Spy Agencies’ Uncertainty
description: The secretary of state cited “enormous evidence” that the virus came from a research laboratory in Wuhan, backing an assertion by President Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Sunday backed President Trump’s assertion that the coronavirus originated in a research laboratory in Wuhan, China, though the nation’s intelligence agencies say they have reached no conclusion on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: More Readers, Fewer Ads: Britain’s Local Newspapers Are Struggling
description: Heavily dependent on advertising and circulation, local and regional newspapers in the U.K. could face financial ruin as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: LONDON — Normally, when Michael Purton has a question for one of his reporters about a story, he shouts it across the newsroom. An answer usually follows within a few seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Contreras, Felix Lopez Barbosa, Asaf Kastner and Isabel Castro
title: Domino’s Is Raking in Money. What About Its Employees?
description: Some Domino’s workers finally got Covid-19 protections, but it took an outbreak and a strike.
content: Some workers, particularly Latino ones, have never had the luxury of sheltering in place during the coronavirus outbreak. The country’s millions of fast food employees can’t continue to ensure pizzas, pasta and salads make it to their destinations, guaranteeing that both their customers and their families are fed, by working from home. These essential workers — most making minimum wage without health benefits — have to fight for basic safeguards from the virus while their employers rake in profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Disruptions Add to Risks for Athletes With Eating Disorders
description: The coronavirus pandemic has disrupted eating and fitness routines, potentially compounding the stress of those, including athletes, who have eating disorders.
content: On a recent weekend, feeling bored and a little out of sorts, the tennis player Madison Keys whipped up a batch of chocolate chip cookies at her home in Orlando, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Kashmir Gun Battle Kills at Least 7
description: Fighting between the Indian Army and militants threatened to heighten hostilities in the disputed region, where near-daily skirmishes have raged for weeks.
content: NEW DELHI — A gun battle between the Indian Army and militants in Kashmir left at least seven people dead, Indian officials said on Sunday, and the violence threatened to heighten tensions in the disputed region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech, Alissa J. Rubin, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ruth Maclean
title: The Covid-19 Riddle: Why Does the Virus Wallop Some Places and Spare Others?
description: Experts are trying to figure out why the coronavirus is so capricious. The answers could determine how to best protect ourselves and how long we have to.
content: The coronavirus has killed so many people in Iran that the country has resorted to mass burials, but in neighboring Iraq, the body count is fewer than 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: George W. Bush Calls for End to Pandemic Partisanship
description: In a video, the former president, who generally avoids speaking out on current affairs, urged Americans to “remember how small our differences are” in a time of crisis. President Trump swiped at him in response.
content: WASHINGTON — Former President George W. Bush called on Americans on Saturday to put aside partisan differences, heed the guidance of medical professionals and show empathy for those stricken by the coronavirus and the resulting economic devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Domino’s Is Raking in Money. What About Its Employees?
description: Some Domino’s workers finally got Covid-19 protections, but it took an outbreak and a strike.
content: Some workers, particularly Latino ones, have never had the luxury of sheltering in place during the coronavirus outbreak. The country’s millions of fast food employees can’t continue to ensure pizzas, pasta and salads make it to their destinations, guaranteeing that both their customers and their families are fed, by working from home. These essential workers — most making minimum wage without health benefits — have to fight for basic safeguards from the virus while their employers rake in profits.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The little blue coupe’s journey shows how ordinary things played out in extraordinary circumstances.
content: Imagine what it would have been like to unwittingly arrange to buy an oxcart in Pompeii on or about the 23rd of August, 79 A.D. — I’m the 21st-century version of that guy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pompeo Blames Wuhan Lab for Coronavirus As Backlash Against China Grows
description: European plans for reopening have prompted protests and sown confusion, and the band U2 has helped get protective gear to Ireland.
content: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As I Came Up the Stairs to Street Level, I Spied a Shining Lincoln Head’
description: A lucky penny in Midtown, navigating slushy streets and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Reopening, Vaccine, Spring Gardens: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Hotel Group Will Return Tens of Millions in Small Business Loans
description: Ashford Inc., which has come under scrutiny after receiving at least $70 million in Paycheck Protection Program loans, said on Saturday that it would return the money.
content: One of the biggest beneficiaries of the government’s small business lending program said on Saturday that its companies will return at least $70 million in loans received through the Paycheck Protection Program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Williams
title: Maintenance Tips for a Virus-Idled Car
description: Advice from Dad, and some experts, on what to do now that we’re driving so much less.
content: Every January during my early teenage years, my parents would fly to Miami to spend about six weeks in the sun. They’d leave the car — usually a Pontiac, one time a Cadillac — in our driveway in Boston, along with some instructions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Last refuge for Homeless, Subway Is Risk
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 3, 2020.
content: “At the end of the day, we understand that this is a very dangerous situation people are going through. But before this, homeless people were already going through a dangerous situation.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 3, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 3, 2020.
content: An article on Page 6 about the filmmaker Alice Wu misstates the given name of her firefighter friend. It is CJ, not TJ.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr, Noah Throop and Aaron Byrd
title: Concert for One: I.C.U. Doctor Brings Classical Music to Coronavirus Patients
description: Dr. Rachel Easterwood, a professionally trained musician-turned-physician, has found a unique way to help her patients with Covid-19 — live classical music concerts.
content: Dr. Rachel Easterwood, a professionally trained musician-turned-physician, has found a unique way to help her patients with Covid-19 — live classical music concerts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: One of Amazon’s Most Powerful Critics Lives in Its Backyard
description: Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington tried to keep her concerns about the company private. Now she’s going public.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Pramila Jayapal was walking a fine line when she arrived at Amazon’s Seattle headquarters on a chilly day last October to meet with some of the company’s top executives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: My Co-Anchor Is Pawing at the Door: Back to You in the Studio
description: As TV meteorologists and reporters work from home, pets have become a part of their reports — often by accident, and always to delightful effect.
content: Scott Connell, a Missouri weatherman, was trying to record a tease last month, but Maple, his Cavalier King Charles spaniel, had other plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Race, Loyalty and Transparency in an Artist’s Lawsuit
description: Did a gallery that helped black artists in the 1980s also take advantage of them? Howardena Pindell is seeking the return of almost two dozen works. Other artists say the gallery skipped payments.
content: For many African-American artists looking for gallery representation in the 1980s, George N’Namdi was the only game in town. One of the few black art dealers, then and now, Mr. N’Namdi opened his first gallery in Detroit in 1981 and focused on black artists working in abstraction. They had been largely ignored by the mainstream art world and marginalized, as well, within black communities that expected their artists to make socially and politically oriented work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Yeh
title: Percival Everett Has a Book or Three Coming Out
description: “Telephone,” a novel whose multiple versions were originally intended as a secret before the coronavirus pandemic, is the latest from a rule-breaking writer.
content: Once you’ve finished “Telephone,” the latest book by Percival Everett, you may be talking about it with another reader and finding that you disagree on what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Shimabukuro
title: One Bright Thing: Reader Edition
description: After 18 of our writers shared a silver lining during the pandemic, more than 300 people sent in submissions of their own luminous moments. Here’s a selection.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: The Coronavirus Becomes a Battle Cry for U.S. Extremists
description: White supremacists seek to stoke the fear and disruption caused by the pandemic to push their agenda and to recruit.
content: America’s extremists are attempting to turn the coronavirus pandemic into a potent recruiting tool both in the deep corners of the internet and on the streets of state capitals by twisting the public health crisis to bolster their white supremacist, anti-government agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North and South Korea Exchange Gunfire Across Demilitarized Zone
description: The reports of gunfire came two days after the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, reappeared in public after three weeks of absence and rumors about his health.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Gunshots fired from North Korea struck a guard post in South Korea on Sunday inside the Demilitarized Zone separating the two countries, and South Korean soldiers fired back, the South’s military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Virus Pushes a Staid Supreme Court Into Revolutionary Changes
description: The court is set to depart from history twice on Monday: The justices will hear arguments by conference call, and the public will be able to listen in.
content: WASHINGTON — A few months ago, a coalition of news organizations asked the Supreme Court to allow live audio coverage of major arguments on gay rights and immigration. Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. rejected the request within hours, in keeping with longstanding practice at an institution that almost never departs from tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Hotel Group Will Return Tens of Millions in Small Business Loans
description: Ashford Inc., which has come under scrutiny after receiving at least $70 million in Paycheck Protection Program loans, said on Saturday that it would return the money.
content: One of the biggest beneficiaries of the government’s small business lending program said on Saturday that its companies will return at least $70 million in loans received through the Paycheck Protection Program.
source.name: The New York Times

title: My Co-Anchor Is Pawing at the Door: Back to You in the Studio
description: As TV meteorologists and reporters work from home, pets have become a part of their reports — often by accident, and always to delightful effect.

title: Maintenance Tips for a Virus-Idled Car
description: Advice from Dad, and some experts, on what to do now that we’re driving so much less.
content: Every January during my early teenage years, my parents would fly to Miami to spend about six weeks in the sun. They’d leave the car — usually a Pontiac, one time a Cadillac — in our driveway in Boston, along with some instructions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Warren Buffett’s Optimistic? Pessimistic? No, Realistic
description: Between the lines of “You can bet on America” were warnings not to be overconfident in predicting what the future might hold.
content: You could always count on the folksy and cheery optimism of Warren Buffett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Aimee Ortiz
title: Sam Lloyd, ‘Scrubs’ Actor, Dies at 56
description: Mr. Lloyd appeared in dozens of television shows and films in his career, including “Seinfeld,” “Modern Family” and “The West Wing.”
content: Sam Lloyd, a longtime television and film actor who appeared in the television shows “Scrubs” and “Desperate Housewives,” died on Thursday at the Barlow Respiratory Hospital  in Los Angeles. He was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Contreras and Felix Lopez
title: Domino’s Is Raking in Money. What About Its Employees?
description: Some Domino’s workers finally got Covid-19 protections, but it took an outbreak and a strike.
content: Some Domino’s workers finally got Covid-19 protections, but it took an outbreak and a strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shahdabul Faraz
title: President Trump, I Am Not Your Enemy. I Am a Doctor.
description: For now, my future and that of other immigrants in America remains uncertain.
content: BOSTON — On April 20, I had just gotten home from a particularly difficult 14-hour shift when I saw President Trump’s tweet about closing the United States border to immigrants. He said that he was acting as a response to the coronavirus pandemic and to protect the jobs of American citizens. This was alarming news to me, especially since some of the reporting on the announcement suggested that visas for highly skilled workers could also be banned. As a foreign-born doctor on a work visa, I was very worried about how this would impact my ability to remain in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyson Belanger
title: The Coronavirus Is Killing Too Many Nursing Home Residents
description: Here’s one idea for protecting them.
content: BRISTOL, Conn. — My family has owned an assisted living home in this town for over 44 years. Both of my grandmothers have lived in it, and my mother might soon need its care. As much as I admired my parents, I did not think I would someday lead it. I went to Yale, served three tours in Iraq as a Marine infantry officer and earned a Ph.D. in political science from Harvard. I had planned to turn my dissertation into a book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luc Sante
title: Andy Warhol, Superstar
description: Blake Gopnik’s mammoth biography traces the life and career of the original King of Pop.
content: WARHOL
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Sunday Read’: Alone at Sea
description: In this time of isolation, listen to this story of a man well acquainted with it.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Like Neon and Argon
description: Emily Carroll’s puzzle takes us on a flight of fantasy.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, everyone! Emily Carroll returns with a fun puzzle for us all to solve from our individual nests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Fly Him to the Moon. Or at Least, Fly Him Home.
description: A shipboard entertainer is among those who have been quarantined for weeks on a cruise ship near Barbados. Stuck in his deluxe cabin, he has an audience of one.
content: Ryan Driscoll is the sort of celebrity unique to luxury cruise lines. A singer and entertainer, dapper and dandy, he plays the big room at night, crooning like Sinatra and Darin. He spends days schmoozing by the pool and strolling the decks, handing out smiles and leaving behind swoons. He belts out arias at sunset. If you are lucky, he is assigned to your table for dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: On Subways as Riders Return: Odes to Their Resilience
description: Leaders of the “Poetry in Motion” program hope verse can help to comfort and encourage people as they return to the trains in greater numbers.
content: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will use many tools in coming weeks in its effort to restore faith in a subway system that has been seen as a vector for infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Ben Protess
title: Trump Nominee Is Among Judges Opposed to Banning Membership in Conservative Group
description: Judge Justin Walker joined a bevy of judges, many appointees of the president, in railing against an ethics proposal on the Federalist Society.
content: As the Senate this week considers elevating a politically connected judge to an influential federal appeals court, the judge has stepped into a fierce ideological debate about a legal group shaping President Trump’s rightward overhaul of the judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: These Are the Bedside Concerts Comforting Virus Patients
description: An I.C.U. doctor felt despair at how little could be done for the sick. Soon, she had musicians playing over the phone in hospital rooms.
content: In chaotic emergency rooms and intensive care units around New York City, coronavirus patients struggle to survive in isolation, with masked doctors and nurses keeping their distance and family visits barred. Alarms, monitors and overhead announcements blare incessantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Leaders Are Crying on the Job. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
description: Politicians. Chief executives. Newscasters. In the pandemic, the old rules of who is allowed to cry in public are changing.
content: Charlie Baker, the Republican governor of Massachusetts, broke down while speaking about the death of his best friend’s mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Why Biden’s Choice of Running Mate Has Momentous Implications
description: Joe Biden has hinted that he might serve only one term if he wins. That would set up a woman as the front-runner for 2024 and perhaps define the Democratic agenda for the next decade.
content: WASHINGTON — For decades the vice-presidential selection process has had an air of cloak-and-dagger to it. The party’s nominees would say little about their thinking, the would-be running mates would reveal even less, and an elaborate game of subterfuge would unfold that mostly captivated political insiders and usually had little bearing on the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Face Masks and Crowd Control: The Race to Make Your Subway Ride Safer
description: Social distancing isn’t easy on the subway. Transit officials are mapping out ways to prepare the system for the return of riders.
content: Businesses in New York City will be asked to change workers’ schedules to reduce rush-hour density on the subway. A new squad of guards will patrol stations, reporting overcrowding to supervisors and directing riders to emptier train cars. Brightly colored markers will be added to encourage riders to keep a distance from one another on platforms, following the advice of transit agencies in China, Singapore and Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Man Camped on Disney World Island at Shuttered Park, Police Say
description: Richard J. McGuire told the police that Discovery Island, an 11-acre zoological park with aromatic trees and walk-through aviaries that closed in 1999, looked like a “tropical paradise.”
content: It had the makings of an adventure straight from Disney’s “Swiss Family Robinson” — being on an uninhabited island and living off the land.
source.name: The New York Times
